title: 112_s965
content: The "Family Act of 2011" may be cited as the official title of this Act. Congress acknowledges infertility as a disease recognized by the World Health Organization and a public health concern according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Approximately 3,000,000 individuals are affected by infertility. Medical insurance coverage for infertility treatments is limited, with only 8 States mandating comprehensive coverage, excluding most employer-sponsored plans. In vitro fertilization is covered by 19 percent of large employer-sponsored health plans. Coverage for in vitro fertilization is limited, with only 19 percent of large employer-sponsored health plans and 11 percent of small employer-sponsored health plans offering it. Out-of-pocket expenses for these treatments remain significant even in States with coverage mandates. SEC. 23A. CREDIT FOR CERTAIN INFERTILITY TREATMENTS. This section introduces a tax credit for infertility treatments. Tax credit of 50% for qualified infertility treatment expenses, up to $13,360 per eligible individual per year. Income limitations apply to reduce the credit amount. The tax credit for infertility treatment expenses is reduced based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income exceeding $150,000, with a limit of $40,000. Adjusted gross income is calculated without considering specific sections. No double benefit is allowed for the credit. Adjusted gross income for the purposes of the tax credit is determined without considering certain sections. No double benefit is allowed for the credit, including expenses covered by other deductions or reimbursements. The tax credit program limits reimbursement for expenses covered by insurance policies and sets a cap based on tax liability for the taxable year. Unused credits can be carried forward. The tax credit program limits reimbursement for expenses covered by insurance policies and sets a cap based on tax liability for the taxable year. Unused credits can be carried forward, subject to certain rules outlined in section 55. The tax credit program limits reimbursement for expenses covered by insurance policies and sets a cap based on tax liability for the taxable year. Unused credits can be carried forward, subject to certain rules outlined in section 55. In cases where the credit exceeds the limitation imposed for a taxable year, the excess can be carried over to the succeeding taxable year. No credit may be carried forward beyond the 5th taxable year after the credit arose, and credits are treated on a first-in first-out basis. The tax credit program limits reimbursement for expenses covered by insurance policies and sets a cap based on tax liability for the taxable year. Unused credits can be carried forward, subject to certain rules outlined in section 55. Credits must be used on a first-in first-out basis and cannot be carried forward beyond the 5th taxable year after they arose. Qualified infertility treatment expenses include in vitro fertilization administered by a licensed medical practitioner for a diagnosis of infertility. Expenses for fertility preservation procedures conducted before medical treatments that may cause infertility are considered qualified infertility treatment expenses, regardless of subsequent infertility diagnosis. Infertility is defined as the inability to conceive or carry a pregnancy to live birth, including infertility caused by medical treatments. Expenses for fertility preservation procedures before treatments that may result in infertility are considered qualified infertility treatment expenses. Eligible individuals are those diagnosed with infertility by a licensed physician. For tax purposes, an eligible individual is someone diagnosed with infertility by a licensed physician. Married taxpayers must file joint returns, and adjustments for inflation apply to dollar limitations starting after December 31, 2012. Starting after December 31, 2012, dollar amounts in subsection (b)(1) and (b)(2)(A)(i) will be increased based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year. Amounts not multiples of $10 will be rounded. "Income limitation for taxable years after December 31, 2002 will be increased based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year. Amounts not multiples of $10 will be rounded." The income limitation for taxable years after December 31, 2002 will be increased based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year. Amounts not multiples of $10 will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. Sec. 23A allows for a credit for certain infertility treatments. Various sections of the Code are amended to include references to section 23A. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2011.
